newsitem.title: YEMEN: Negotiations in Yemen seek to free U.S. hostage.
newsitem.headline: Negotiations in Yemen seek to free U.S. hostage.

text.p: Yemeni security forces have laid siege to mountain tribesmen holding a U.S. oil engineer hostage in the rugged interior of the country, security sources said on Tuesday.

Joe D'ellaire, an engineer working for the U.S. engineering group Halliburton, was abducted on February 10 in the eastern Marib governorate by members of the Murad tribe, angered by a dispute over land with Yemeni officials.

The sources said the kidnappers were demanding compensation of $2 million or the return of a piece of land in the capital Sanaa they say was given to one of the tribal leaders, Sheikh Abdullah Abdrabu al-Mansouri.
"The al-Juba district in the governorate of Marib has been under siege since late Sunday night," one source told Reuters.
Halliburton said in a statement it was working diligently with the Yemeni authorities to secure their employee's release.
"We have been allowed to deliver food and clothing to the employee through our negotiator and all indications are that he is in good condition," the statement said.
"The tribesmen are holding the employee hostage in connection with a dispute with the government of Yemen," it added.
The kidnappers, who are followers of Sheikh Abdullah, say land near the presidential palace had been donated to the tribal leader and later taken back by the Sanaa municipality.
Other leaders of the Murad tribe were also negotiating with Sheikh Abdullah's followers for the release of the American engineer, sources close to the negotiations said.
They did not say whether the other tribal chiefs were leading the talks on behalf of the government.
D'ellaire was abducted from Rig 1 on the Saad al-Kamel oilfield, about 300 km (185 miles) east of Sanaa, oil industry officials said.
He was one of 125 men stationed on the rig, they said.
In recent years, Yemeni tribes with grievances against the government or foreign oil firms have kidnapped scores of tourists, diplomats or other foreigners to use as bargaining chips.
The hostages, who have included an oil man from the private U.S. company Hunt Oil and another from U.S. oil services company Nabors Industries Inc, were all released unharmed.
Halliburton said its primary objective was to win the release of their employee.

"Appropriate actions have been and are being taken to achieve these objectives," the company said. "In the interests of the well-being of the employee, no additional information is being provided at this time."
